newsitem.title: BOLIVIA: Andean ministers to meet in Lima on free trade.
newsitem.headline: Andean ministers to meet in Lima on free trade.

text.p: Foreign ministers from the five Andean nations will meet within the next 15 days in Lima to discuss their plans to seek free trade with the Mercosur bloc, a senior Bolivian official said Wednesday.

The ministers will discuss whether the five Andean Pact members Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru and Venezuela will negotiate with the Mercosur customs union as a group or whether Bolivia and Peru would do it separately, Bolivia's Deputy Foreign Minister Victor Rico told reporters.

"That has not been decided yet," he said after the five Andean Pact presidents met in this central Bolivian city on the fringes of the 10th Rio Group of Latin American nations summit winding up later Wednesday.
Colombia said Tuesday that Andean Pact trade ministers will meet in Caracas next week to discuss their upcoming negotiations with Mercosur, which comprises Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay.

Panama, a country with close ties to the Andean Pact, has also requested free trade with the five-nation group, Rico said. The Andean leaders instructed their ministers to start talks with Panama as soon as possible, he said.
Virtually all Latin American countries have now cast aside protectionistic and isolationistic practices of the past, adopting regional economic integration as their watchword.
Chile has negotiated a free-trade deal with Mercosur and other countries, including Mexico have expressed interest in a pact as well.
